executive_summary: As an almost brand-new industry, industrial hemp production is currently in a period of explosive growth. Industrial hemp, which has become synonymous with the simplified term hemp, is a variety of cannabis with only trace amounts of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). With very few exceptions, hemp production was illegal in the US until 2018. The 2018 Farm Bill legalized hemp growing because the hemp grown has a THC content of less than 0.3% by weight. Upon legalization, industrial hemp production boomed as companies rapidly entered the industry to take advantage of the high demand for hemp-based products. Over the five years to 2023, revenue grew at a CAGR of 12.7% to $253.5 million.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When hemp production was fully legalized in 2018, a high level of demand was already present, priming new growers for success. The market for hemp-based products had been established through imports and USDA trial production. With the legalization of hemp production, a wave of economic possibilities flooded in. From farmers finding a lucrative alternative crop to entrepreneurs exploring the possibilities of hemp-derived products, this catalyzed job creation and revenue streams. Since the 2018 Farm Bill was passed, hemp production has begun to stabilize as entry to the industry has slowed and the novelty of the industry has passed.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Outbreak of COVID-19 Disrupted Explosive Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While hemp production revenue surged immediately following legalization, that growth stalled in 2020 during the height of the pandemic. With shipping disrupted as people could not work, there was no way for many hemp.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: U.S. Struggles to Find a Place in Global Market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Though the US legalized hemp production in 2018, many countries have had legal hemp for decades. This has made it difficult for domestic growers to penetrate the global market. China, Italy, Romania and the Netherlands are the world's biggest hemp suppliers and contribute the majority of hemp imports to the US. While US growers have been able to make business connections abroad, the global market is highly competitive, making it a challenge to stand out.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Hemp Finds Its Place Despite Reputation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Even though hemp contains less than 0.3% THC, it is closely associated with marijuana since both originate in the cannabis plant. Many consumers do not know the difference between marijuana and hemp, creating the misconception that hemp has psychoactive effects, creating a negative association in many consumers' minds.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted the economy and its aftermath, consumer spending and capital investment levels are projected to grow over the next five years. Hemp farms rely on consumer spending and private investment to grow their sales and expand operations. With economic recovery comes increased spending power, spurring demand for hemp-derived products, from textiles to CBD-infused goods. Hemp is often grown under a protective covering, so hemp production resists volatile weather patterns and revenue is less likely to swing between years.

As public perception of the drug has changed, there has been an influx of states decriminalizing and legalizing medical and recreational marijuana. When they become more comfortable with marijuana, the stigma around hemp will fall and consumer demand will grow. The legalization of marijuana also indirectly benefits the hemp industry by creating an opportunity for growers to leverage shared resources, infrastructure and expertise in their favor. Some consumers see CBD products as a legal and safe alternative to marijuana, but if marijuana becomes more widely available, demand for CBD could slow.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GROWING ACCEPTANCE OF HEMP USE WILL LEAD TO MARKET DIVERSIFICATION
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As legal barriers dissolve, growing public acceptance will continue to open doors for diverse hemp-derived products, from textiles to construction materials. Beyond the traditional use in textiles and ropes, hemp finds applications in construction materials, biofuels, paper, and even bioplastics. This diversification creates revenue streams and stimulates innovation and investment in research and development. Research into the varied applications of hemp will continue to gain momentum. An influx of investment should spark technological advancements that propel the industry forward.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ECO-CONSCIOUSNESS IN CONSUMERS WILL IMPACT ACTIVITY IN THE INDUSTRY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A global shift towards eco-conscious consumerism has occurred, propelling demand for organic hemp products thanks to their biodegradability and versatility. Eco-conscious consumers will continue to drive demand for sustainably produced hemp.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry grow and harvest cannabis plants with a tetrahyrdocannabidinol (THC) content of less than 0.3% by weight.

negative_impact_factors: Revenue Volatility Level is very high

strengths: Industries are integrating hemp into biodegradable packaging, reducing their reliance on non-biodegradable materials like plastics. This move aligns with corporate sustainability agendas, marking hemp as a key player in reducing environmental waste.

Consumers are increasingly scrutinizing the environmental impact of their purchases, prompting farmers to adopt organic farming practices. Efforts to minimize energy consumption, optimize water usage and reduce waste in hemp cultivation and processing are gaining traction.

key_trends: Hemp legalization led to massive growth. The market for hemp has already been established during trials, so the new industry had minimal growing pains.
Association with marijuana limits growth. In pushing for legalization, farms and industry groups have educated the public on the difference between hemp and marijuana.
Hemp was federally legalized in 2018
Though farming of hemp has been permitted for a few years now, many states continue to consider hemp a controlled substance.
Hemp demand is closely linked with marijuana demand. Both grow as people become more comfortable with cannabis.
CBD products fuel demand for hemp
Consumers have recently discovered the relaxing effects of CBD, creating massive demand for hemp.
Hemp fibers are the strongest natural fibers
While it can't compete with synthetic textiles, hemp is used to make strong natural textiles.
The Plains region provides ideal space and weather
Hemp plants need ample space and warm weather for optimal growth.
Hemp is not legal in every state
While hemp production is federally legal, many states continue to consider hemp a controlled substance.
Pharmaceuticals and marijuana threaten CBD products
CBD is used to treat anxiety, depression and other mental health symptoms.
Hemp producers compete with other textile producers
While hemp can be used for strong natural textiles, it must build its market presence.
No major companies have emerged in the Hemp Production Industry
As a new industry, no companies have had the chance to claim significant market share.
Automation has yet to lower labor costs
Hemp-growing technology has yet to advance enough to replace workers.
Only female hemp plants produce CBD oil
The rarity of female hemp seeds makes purchase costs high.

products_and_services.product_description: CBD is the chemical in marijuana that gives users a relaxed feeling and can be used to treat anxiety, depression and other mental health symptoms. Many users prefer CBD because it provides the benefits of marijuana without the psychoactive effects of THC. The benefits of CBD were among the factors that led to the legalization of hemp production, and demand for CBD provided the industry with an immediate market.

Hemp seeds are prized in personal care products for their rich source of omega fatty acids, which nourish and moisturize the skin, promoting a healthy complexion and aiding in hair strength and growth.

Hemp fibers, known for their strength and durability, are extensively utilized in industrial applications. They have increasingly been used in automotive manufacturing, construction materials, paper production and textiles, due to their eco-friendly and versatile nature.

Hemp seeds are quickly becoming the latest super food trend, getting incorporated into supplements and food products. Since it's legalization, hemp farms have found opportunities in the health foods market which is increasingly profitable. Hemp seeds have grown in popularity among consumers that want to follow healthy natural diets. Hemp leaves are rarely prepared for human consumption, so most hemp-based food is made using hemp seeds.

Before cannabis was outlawed in the US, hemp was most commonly used to make ropes and other textiles due to its naturally strong fibers. While hemp can't compare to the strength of synthetic fibers, hemp is the strongest naturally available fiber. Hemp will need to break away from its association with marijuana before it can establish a strong foothold in the textile market.

tier_2_suppliers: Tractors & Agricultural Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: PROCESSED AND PHARMACEUTICAL HEMP PRODUCTS SUPPORT STEADY DEMAND
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The majority of US hemp is processed into consumer products like soap, food and textiles. A significant portion of this market is pharmaceutical and supplement manufacturers that extract CBD oil and make CBD products, which have been in high demand in recent years. Hemp processors are more likely to purchase hemp in bulk, making this market reliable for hemp farmers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: SPECIALTY RETAILERS AND CONSUMERS PURCHASE RAW HEMP
demand_determinants.determinant_description: While CBD oil and processed hemp are the most common hemp-based products, smoke shops and internet retailers often sell raw hemp for smoking. Hemp can be smoked like marijuana, but unlike marijuana, smoking hemp has no psychoactive effects. Farms sell raw hemp directly to consumers, smoke shops and other specialty retailers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Research Allows Farms to Explore Other Markets
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As a newly legalized product, hemp is still finding new uses and markets. Some farms have explored using hemp as an animal feed crop, creating another potential market.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Plummet After USDA Legalized Hemp
international_trade_points.trade_description: Before farming was legalized in the US, downstream markets relied on imports. Since 2018, when hemp production was legalized, the value of imports have declined because hemp is now more easily available in the US. While imports initially remained high following hemp legalization, it took a few years for domestic production to increase and replace the need for imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: ROMANIAN IMPORTS REMAIN STEADY WHILE CANADIAN IMPORTS FALL
international_trade_points.trade_description: Before the value of hemp imports fell in 2021, Canada was the country's largest supplier of industrial hemp. Canada has a long history of legal hemp, so when the US began researching hemp, Canadian farms were the logical supplier of that hemp. Now that the US can produce its own hemp, Romania represents the largest supplier of imported hemp, though it still accounts for only a small fraction of domestic demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: US HEMP FARMERS HAVE YET TO MAKE A MARK ON THE GLOBAL MARKET
international_trade_points.trade_description: While the US recently legalized hemp production, other countries have had legal hemp for decades. While the value of exports has surged since 2018, exports account for less than 2.0% of hemp farming revenue. With a young industry, the US is a small player in the global market for hemp.

business_locations.location_description: Successful farming depends on the right mix of sunshine and rain. For this reason, the largest concentration of harvested acres of hemp is in the Plains region. The central states get more direct sunshine, especially in the summer months, resulting in an ideal growing climate.
Oklahoma has flat terrain, ample sunshine and seasonal rain. Kansas is also a top producing state due to favorable weather conditions.
Similar to Oklahoma, Montana has favorable terrain and weather, providing farmers with accommodative tools.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The 2018 Farm Bill legalized the production of industrial hemp. Under the Farm Bill, the Department of Agriculture issues hemp growing licenses and requires that all US hemp be tested for THC levels.
The Controlled Substance Act (CSA) classifies THC as an illegal drug that has the potential for abuse. Under the CSA, hemp plants cannot contain more than 0.3% THC.
Individual states are allowed to enforce their own laws regulating hemp sales and production within their own borders. However, law enforcement is not permitted to restrict hemp transportation.

basis_points.basis_title: Pharmaceuticals and marijuana threaten CBD products
basis_points.basis_description: CBD is used to treat anxiety, depression and other mental health symptoms.

basis_points.basis_title: Hemp producers compete with other textile producers
basis_points.basis_description: While hemp can be used for strong natural textiles, it must build its market presence.

concentration_points.concentration_title: MAJOR COMPANIES ARE YET TO EMERGE
concentration_points.concentration_description: As a young industry, the Industrial Hemp Production industry has a low level of market share concentration with no company accounting for more than 5.0% of revenue.
Major companies will eventually emerge once the industry is well-established and large companies have the chance to grow through M&A activity.
The variance in regulations across different states leads to a fragmented market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rare Hemp Seeds Lead to Heightened Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs are expected to account for 8.6% of industry revenue in 2023, a major decline from 17.4% in 2018. Hemp seeds account for the majority of purchase costs, but due to a rise in wage costs and disruption to revenue growth, growers were forced to significantly cut corners where they could.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Automation Has Yet to Bring Down High Labor Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As a new industry, most farms don't have proper automated planting and harvesting equipment. Farm equipment manufacturers have yet to invest in hemp equipment because the industry had previously been illegal. Without easily available equipment, most hemp production needs to be done by hand. In 2023, labor costs are expected to account for 68.8% of total industry revenue, a significant rise from 53.4% in 2018 since revenue fluctuated as employment grew.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Hemp farming equipment is still not widely available
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Hemp farming equipment is still not widely available, so hemp farming still relies heavily on labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatility Skyrockets With Legal Status Change
volatility_points.volatility_description: Hemp production revenue surged in 2019 after the 2018 Farm Bill legalized hemp growing in much of the US. Before 2019, hemp could only be grown through a USDA pilot program or in rare situations. Since 2020, hemp production revenue has stabilized as the USDA has regulated production and the industry has become a part of the Agriculture sector.

FAQs.question: What is the regulation and policy environment for the hemp industry?
FAQs.answer: The 2018 Farm Bill legalized the production of industrial hemp in the US. The Department of Agriculture issues hemp growing licenses and requires that all US hemp be tested for THC levels below 0.3%. Individual states can enforce their own laws regulating hemp sales and production within their borders, but cannot restrict hemp transportation across state lines.

FAQs.question: What industry assistance is available for hemp growers?
FAQs.answer: The US Hemp Growers Association (USHGA) is a non-profit that supports hemp growers through education, networking and research. It keeps growers updated on legal changes and growing techniques.

FAQs.question: What are some key sales and marketing considerations for hemp farms?
FAQs.answer: Many existing farms entered the industry by growing a small amount of hemp along with other crops. Historically, imports have provided nearly all of the US hemp supply, so domestic farms face import competition. When hemp production was legalized, an influx of new producers caused hemp prices to plummet, so farms must cope with market price changes.

FAQs.question: What are some important strategy and operations factors for hemp farms?
FAQs.answer: Key input costs include female hemp seeds needed for CBD production. Farms may engage in their own R&D. Companies are trying to automate operations and invest in new harvesting equipment to improve efficiency. Supply chain and inventory management is critical to prevent spoilage of harvested hemp.

FAQs.question: What are the key technology considerations for hemp farms?
FAQs.answer: Companies are investing in new harvesting machines and other equipment to automate operations and improve efficiency on hemp farms.

FAQs.question: What are the regulatory compliance requirements for hemp farms?
FAQs.answer: Hemp farms must comply with USDA regulations and ensure their crop does not exceed the 0.3% THC legal limit. They can now acquire federal crop insurance. Costs are associated with THC testing to meet the legal threshold.

FAQs.question: How does profitability and financing look for hemp farms?
FAQs.answer: Many companies entered the industry expecting double-digit profit margins, but decreased investment from banks may pose financing challenges for equipment purchases. Hemp farms' profitability compared to competitors is not provided.

FAQs.question: How can hemp farms differentiate and promote their products?
FAQs.answer: Since all hemp is essentially substitutable, farms must work to differentiate their cultivars from competitors through effective product promotion, potentially specializing their products in some way. Specific promotion strategies are not provided.

FAQs.question: How should hemp farms manage inventory and warehousing?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must exercise supply chain and inventory management, ensuring harvests do not sit in warehouses and spoil. Specific stock control and warehousing measures are not provided.

FAQs.question: What are the demand drivers for hemp products?
FAQs.answer: As people become more comfortable with marijuana, regulation of industrial hemp is likely to continue falling, leading to greater demand. Demand may also increase as per capita disposable income rises and people can afford premium CBD products. It is unclear if hemp product demand trends with marijuana product demand or if hemp is sold at dispensaries.
